author: sky.cactus
content: The fear is that presigned cold wallet transfers will break.

author: sky.cactus
content: One suggestion was to introduce a precompile where you could submit old format transactions.  Sort of like EIP-3074, but specifically legacy signed transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is unknown if there exist any such presigned transactions, but it would be a not-unreasonable tiered security model.

author: karalabe
content: Well, we could keep it allowed and only disable forwarding them

author: karalabe
content: Then if you really really want, you could inject it into a miner to have it mined

author: sky.cactus
content: Do we get meaningful gains making them minable but not gossipable?

author: jochembrouwer
content: It would mean that if you want to get a non-EIP155 transaction on the chain, you'd have to jump through extra hoops, so that ensures that this actor **really** wants to get their non-EIP155 transaction mined. So that also ensures that this actor really has a good reason for it (because they will know that they are explicitly putting this non-EIP155 transaction on chain, and thus also should have some level of technical knowledge)

author: sky.cactus
content: I mean what benefits do we have by making it hard for users to send legacy transactions?

author: sky.cactus
content: Does it help us reduce technical debt in some way?

author: jochembrouwer
content: Geth doesn't make it hard to send legacy transactions, it makes it hard to send non-EIP155 legacy transactions

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, the idea is to protect users?  If so, I don't think the clients are the right place to do that.  Really that sort of protection should be done by wallets.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Agreed, unfortunately some wallets still used non-EIP155 signed transactions. That's why we decided that it would be time to gently nudge them to start using them

author: sky.cactus
content: There are legitimate use cases for cross-chain replayable transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: Relatively few, but I'm not a fan of disabling transmission without some benefit (besides doing a job someone else should be doing).

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: I agree, however I don't think these use cases outweigh the cost of users getting rekt/griefed by using a side-chain / L2

author: sky.cactus
content: What do side chains/L2s have to do with this?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: People keep using their accounts across different chains

author: sky.cactus
content: Has this resulted in real problems, or only theoretic?

author: sky.cactus
content: Still feels like "not a Geth problem".

author: karalabe

author: sky.cactus
content: I would favor removing legacy transaction gossip support sometime after 1559 lands, as that would allow clients to cleanup (in theory) some code.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm just a bit leery of encouraging client devs do *more* work because some people messed up on security.

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, client devs can do whatever they want, I just don't think it is the best use of time. ðŸ™‚
